conclusion: To find the effective value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, we need to follow these steps.
The coil is a square with side length L.
The area A of the coil is A = L^2.
The coil rotates at a constant angular velocity Ï‰.
The magnetic flux Î¦ through the coil is given by Î¦ = B Â· A Â· cos(Î¸).
The induced EMF ğ“” is given by Faraday's Law: ğ“” = -N dÎ¦/dt.
The angle Î¸ changes with time as Î¸ = Ï‰t, so Î¦ = B Â· L^2 Â· cos(Ï‰t).
Differentiating Î¦ with respect to time t gives dÎ¦/dt = -B Â· L^2 Â· Ï‰ Â· sin(Ï‰t).
Substituting into Faraday's Law gives ğ“” = N Â· B Â· L^2 Â· Ï‰ Â· sin(Ï‰t).
The effective (RMS) value of the induced EMF is given by ğ“”_rms = ğ“”_max/âˆš2.
The maximum induced EMF occurs when sin(Ï‰t) = 1, so ğ“”_max = N Â· B Â· L^2 Â· Ï‰.
The RMS value is ğ“”_rms = N Â· B Â· L^2 Â· Ï‰/âˆš2.
The effective value of the induced electromotive force in the coil is ğ“”_rms = N Â· B Â· L^2 Â· Ï‰/âˆš2.
